current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To provide that certain uses of a patent or copyright in
		  compliance with an order of the Federal Communications Commission for emergency
		  communications services shall be construed as use or manufacture for the United
		  States.

sponsor.#tail:
introduced
			 the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

short-title.#text:
Protect Advanced Communications
			 for Emergency Services Act of 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited as
			 the

there are an
			 estimated 302,000,000 active wireless mobile device users in the United States
			 with an estimated 51,000,000 people in the United States living in households
			 that rely solely on wireless communication devices (almost 25 percent of
			 households in the United States), of which 21,000,000 are children;

a majority of
			 9–1–1 calls now originate from mobile devices, making an advanced wireless
			 9–1–1 service system a critical national asset for law enforcement, homeland
			 security, and emergency responders who rely on this wireless location-based
			 information to effectively dispatch assistance;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
mandates all wireless phone carriers and IP-enabled
			 voice service providers to provide services enabling users to dial 9–1–1 with a
			 stated purpose of allowing government first responders, homeland security,
			 police, fire and other government public safety officials the ability to
			 accurately locate 9–1–1 callers using wireless devices;

text.#text:
the growing
			 reliance of the people of the United States and public safety, homeland
			 security, and law enforcement officials on emerging wireless technologies is
			 leading to the need for national text to 9–1–1, as well as picture and video
			 9–1–1 capabilities from mobile devices;

emerging
			 technologies can be a critical component of the end-to-end communications
			 infrastructure connecting the public with emergency medical service providers
			 and emergency dispatch providers, public safety, fire service, and law
			 enforcement officials, and hospital emergency and trauma care facilities, to
			 reduce emergency response times and provide appropriate care;

improved public
			 safety remains an important public health objective of Federal, State, and
			 local governments and substantially facilitates interstate and foreign
			 commerce;

wireless carriers
			 and their vendors, in complying with the Federal mandate to provide E–9–1–1
			 location-based technology, have become targets of or been impacted by patent
			 infringement lawsuits;

patent
			 infringement lawsuits brought by what the

deterring the
			 implementation of innovative new technologies that could meet next generation
			 9–1–1 public safety needs such as text, picture, and video 9–1–1
			 capabilities;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, was designed to protect those required by the
			 Government to provide a service
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 1498 of
			 title 28, United States Code

quote.#tail:
while also providing legitimate patent holders with an appropriate means to
			 recover reasonable and entire compensation for their patents;
quote.#text: by or for the United States

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 1498
			 of title 28, United States Code

text.#text:
this Act
			 clarifies that patented technologies required to provide 9–1–1, enhanced 9–1–1,
			 and other emergency communication services, as defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, are provided by and for the United States and with the
			 authorization or consent of the United States for the purposes of

act-name.#text: Wireless Communications and Public Safety Act of 1999

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Wireless Communications and Public Safety Act of 1999/s:7

text.#text:
this Act does
			 not modify or invalidate any patent, preserves all patent claims, and does not
			 prevent patent litigation.
